text: You beat me to it!
author: jackgillum

text: Hey this is great news. Congrats!
author: jackgillum

text: I'll give you an example. In Phoenix -- not exactly a pedestrian haven -- a school zone on a 40 mph road was continually ignored. Police flooded the area for a week to issue citations + publicized the enforcement campaign. A month later, drivers stopped like clockwork.
author: jackgillum

text: Let's not make it an either-or; rolling through stop signs is also dangerous. I suppose DC is just the only city I've lived in where folks want to sign their way out of a problem, rather than just enforcing traffic laws aggressively. The latter just doesn't happen.
author: jackgillum

text:
Believe me, I wish local roads — including mine — weren’t used as a commuter cut-through. But the reality is they are. 

All the design won’t change the fact that drivers’ aggressive behavior needs curbed. It’s why is feel unsafe cycling even on the best designed roads in DC
author: jackgillum

text: http://www.dot.state.oh.us/districts/D01/PlanningPrograms/trafficstudies/Documents/Intersection-Safety-myth-versus-reality.pdf …
author: jackgillum

text:
It speaks to the reality of roadway design, not kowtowing to motorists. If putting up more stop signs leads to greater chance of their ignoring subsequent stops, we should probably heed that reality. 

Besides, stopping for pedestrians in a crosswalk is the law. Let’s enforce it.
author: jackgillum

text: Better alternative is more enforcement, even a HAWK. I’ve been told by engineers that lots of stop signs have the unintended, ironic effect of leading to more dangerous drivers because they’re furious with too many stops.
author: jackgillum

text: @DDOTDC @311DCgov pothole open for weeks in front of 1831 5th Street NW. any way it can get fixed? Thanks.
